text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man needs to transport a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage across a river.
He has a small boat that can only carry himself and one item at a time.
If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, and the goat would eat the cabbage.

How can the man transport all three items across the river without any of them being eaten? 

 Solution:

He can only take himself and one item at a time in his small boat.
The problem is that if the wolf and goat are left together, the wolf will eat the goat, and if the goat and cabbage are left together, the goat will eat the cabbage.
I need to figure out how the man can get all three items across without any of them getting eaten.
Hmm, let me start by breaking down the problem.
The man can only take one item at a time, so he has to make multiple trips.
The key is to prevent the wolf and goat from being alone together, and the goat and cabbage from being alone together.

The man can take one item each trip, so he'll have to go back and forth across the river.

That leaves taking the cabbage first.

The wolf would eat the goat, so that's not good either.
Hmm, so taking any one of them first seems to leave a dangerous pair behind.

The wolf and goat can't be together, and the goat and cabbage can't be together.
So, perhaps the man needs to alternate between taking the wolf and the cabbage, leaving the goat on the starting side temporarily.

But wait, the man can't leave the wolf alone on the far side because he needs to come back.
So if he takes the wolf over, he has to bring it back, but that would require leaving the goat and cabbage alone again, which is not allowed.
Alternatively, maybe he takes the wolf over first, but then instead of leaving it, he takes something else back.
